jem_answer: NNK is a tobacco-specific nitrosamine which is formed during the curing and smoking of tobacco. It is found in both mainstream smoke and in sidestream smoke. NNK is carcinogenic in laboratory animals. It is a strong carcinogen which induces lung adenomas in mice, carcinomas in the nasal cavity, liver, and lung of rats, tracheal tumors and carcinomas of the nasal cavity and lung of hamsters. NNK is one of the most powerful carcinogens in tobacco
